security_audit.summary: Legitimate cheminformatics tool that queries the official NCBI PubChem database. All network requests go to pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov government API. The 269 static findings are false positives: markdown code blocks (backticks) were misidentified as shell commands, chemical identifiers (InChI, InChIKey) were flagged as weak crypto, and HTTP requests to official APIs were marked as network activity. No malicious behavior or command injection risks were found.

content.user_title: Search PubChem for chemical compounds and properties
content.value_statement: Finding chemical information requires navigating multiple databases and complex API queries. This skill provides unified access to PubChem database with simple search by name, structure, or identifier plus property retrieval and similarity searches for cheminformatics workflows.
actual_capabilities: Search compounds by name, CID, SMILES, InChI, or molecular formula
Retrieve molecular properties including MW, LogP, TPSA, and hydrogen bonding descriptors
Perform Tanimoto similarity searches to find structurally related compounds
Conduct substructure searches for specific chemical motifs
Access bioactivity data from screening assays and assays by target
Convert between chemical identifier formats and download structure files
limitations: Limited to PubChem database only; no access to other chemical databases
Rate limited to 5 requests per second per official API limits
Similarity and substructure searches may take 15-30 seconds for large queries

use_cases.title: Find similar drug candidates
use_cases.description: Search for compounds structurally similar to known drugs and filter by drug-like properties.

use_cases.title: Retrieve compound properties
use_cases.description: Look up molecular weight, LogP, and other properties for known chemical compounds.

use_cases.title: Access bioactivity data
use_cases.description: Query assay results and find compounds with activity against specific biological targets.

prompt_templates.title: Basic compound search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search PubChem for [compound name] and show its molecular formula, weight, and canonical SMILES.

prompt_templates.title: Similarity search
prompt_templates.prompt: Find [number] compounds similar to [SMILES string] using a Tanimoto threshold of [number].

prompt_templates.title: Substructure search
prompt_templates.prompt: Search PubChem for compounds containing the substructure [SMILES] and return their CIDs and names.

prompt_templates.title: Bioactivity lookup
prompt_templates.prompt: Get bioactivity summary for CID [number] showing assay counts and activity outcomes.

output_examples.input: Search for aspirin and show its properties

output: All compounds have MW < 250 and follow Lipinski rules

best_practices: Use CIDs instead of names for repeated queries to improve speed and reduce ambiguity
Add 0.2-0.3 second delays between requests to respect API rate limits
Cache frequently accessed compound data locally to reduce API calls
anti_patterns: Performing large substructure searches without limiting MaxRecords causing timeouts
Ignoring missing property values instead of checking if properties exist for a compound
Using similarity searches with very low thresholds that return thousands of results

faq.question: Which identifiers can I use to search?
faq.answer: You can search by chemical name, CID (Compound ID), SMILES, InChI, InChIKey, or molecular formula.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of requests?
faq.answer: PubChem limits requests to 5 per second and 400 per minute. Add delays between requests to avoid rate limiting.

faq.question: Can I integrate with other databases?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on PubChem only. For other databases like ChEMBL or DrugBank, use separate integrations.

faq.question: Is my search data kept private?
faq.answer: Search queries are sent to NCBI PubChem servers. No user data is stored or transmitted elsewhere.

faq.question: Why do similarity searches take so long?
faq.answer: Large similarity and substructure searches use asynchronous processing that may take 15-30 seconds to complete.

faq.question: How does this compare to other chemistry tools?
faq.answer: PubChem offers the largest free chemical database. For specialized domains, consider ChEMBL (drugs) or ChEBI (biomolecules).
